conclusion: The frame has a side length l, the magnetic field has a width d and is uniform, the frame moves with a constant velocity v, and we need to find the time during which an induced current exists in the frame.

An induced current will exist in the frame whenever the magnetic flux through the frame changes. The magnetic flux Φ through the frame is given by Φ = B ⋅ A, where B is the magnetic field strength and A is the area of the part of the frame that is inside the magnetic field.

The frame enters the magnetic field when its left edge reaches the left boundary of the magnetic field. The frame exits the magnetic field when its right edge reaches the right boundary of the magnetic field.
The left edge of the frame starts at a distance l from the left boundary of the magnetic field. The time t1 for the left edge to reach the left boundary of the magnetic field is t1 = l/v.

The right edge of the frame exits the magnetic field when it reaches the right boundary of the magnetic field. The total distance the frame needs to travel to exit the magnetic field is d + l. The time t2 for the right edge to reach the right boundary of the magnetic field is t2 = (d + l)/v.

The induced current exists from the moment the left edge enters the magnetic field until the right edge exits the magnetic field. Therefore, the total time T during which there is an induced current is T = t2 - t1 = (d + l)/v - l/v = d/v.
